explanation: The line S = input().split() makes S a list (e.g. ['TTAAT']) instead of the intended string of characters, so S.count('T') and S[-1] behave incorrectly. I changed that line to S = input().strip() so S is the input string (with trailing newline removed) and the subsequent counts and tie-break logic work as intended.
fixed_code:
N = int(input())
S = input().strip()

T_W = S.count('T')
A_W = S.count('A')
print("T" if T_W > A_W or T_W == A_W and S[-1] == "A" else "A")
